results.title: Canopy
results.credit_line:
John Harvey, Saibai Island

Multi-screen installation

Commissioned by ACMI and edited by Patrick McCabe
results.brief_description: John Harvey’s multi-screen installation, Canopy, celebrates and shares First Peoples self-representation while resisting and disrupting popular ideas of Australian identity, place and nationhood too often defined by the white gaze of non-Indigenous filmmakers.

constellations_primary.name: Canopy
constellations_primary.description: John Harvey is a Torres Strait Islander producer, director and writer in screen and stage whose work Canopy celebrates Indigenous self-representation.

results.description:
Throughout the history of screen culture, First Peoples have been portrayed as both an exotic curiosity and stereotypically deficient due to the ‘white gaze’ wielded by non-Indigenous Australians, who often defined First Peoples representation on-screen.

Around the 1970s, First Peoples stepped behind the camera en masse to capture their own story and control their representation, using the lens to return the gaze, look back, and look at each other. While celebrating, practicing and sharing culture, this gaze continues to resist and disrupt popular ideas of Australian identity, place and nationhood.

Canopy continues this tradition and comments on First Peoples self-representation.

“The canopy is teeming with life. It is a place where the biodiversity of species ensures the survival of us all. Through the imagery in my work, I’m exploring layers of being, from the individual to family, clan, culture, country and finally, to consciousness. Canopy invites audiences to still their minds and experience the work as a meditation with an open spirit and heart. It contains my home movies along with films I’ve written and directed.” – John Harvey

While celebrating, practicing and sharing culture, this gaze continues to resist and disrupt popular ideas of Australian identity, place and nationhood.

Canopy continues this tradition and comments on First Peoples self-representation.

“The canopy is teeming with life. It is a place where the biodiversity of species ensures the survival of us all. Through the imagery in my work, I’m exploring layers of being, from the individual to family, clan, culture, country and finally, to consciousness. results.title: Canon
results.creator_credit: Grant Munro, Norman McLaren and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: In its simplest form the canon is a kind of singing game, a round for voices where each singer picks up the words and tune, a beat or so after the preceding one. Norman McLaren and Grant Munro demonstrate, by animation and live action, how a canon works. A child’s blocks are used in a checkerboard to illustrate the form of Frere Jacques. Two additional canons specially written for the film by Eldon Rathburn are acted out. Five awards, including Toronto.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Grant Munro, Norman McLaren and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Capital city
results.creator_credit: Carl Thomson, Richard Taylor, Antony Barrier and Antony Barrier Productions
results.brief_description: The City of London covers only one square mile, yet it is the most sophisticated money market in the world. Behind the tradition of the election of the Lord Mayor and the ancient Liveries Companies we are shown how the City of London sets about its complex task of providing a balanced environment for its working people and residents.

results.title: Candle-lit film-strip projector
results.brief_description:
Purchased for display in SOMI, replace Kinora on loan from MAAS
Maker probably Veb, Zett or Noris
https://www.ebay.com.au/itm/154670058741
results.description:
Early magic lantern projections depicted cautionary religious and supernatural scenes, like sinners roasting in Purgatory and Death wielding a scythe. Magic lanterns weren’t used only by clergymen though, but also by a wide variety of entertainers and educators in homes, theatres and universities. While performers told jokes and fairytales, travelling showmen unveiled exotic locations, scientists revealed the latest discoveries and charlatan magicians spooked audiences with dancing skeletons.

Magic lanterns were made in all shapes and sizes from materials as diverse as biscuit tins and brass to mahogany and nickel. They were even mass-produced as children’s toys in the 19th century.
description_for_label:

Magic lanterns weren’t used only by clergymen though, but also by a wide variety of entertainers and educators in homes, theatres and universities. While performers told jokes and fairytales, travelling showmen unveiled exotic locations, scientists revealed the latest discoveries and charlatan magicians spooked audiences with dancing skeletons.

Magic lanterns were made in all shapes and sizes from materials as diverse as biscuit tins and brass to mahogany and nickel. They were even mass-produced as children’s toys in the 19th century.

results.title: Cannibal Tours
results.creator_credit: Dennis O'Rourke, Chris Owen and Laurence J. Henderson
results.brief_description: This witty, charming film follows a group of rich and bourgeois tourists on a journey along the Sepik River in the jungles of Papua New Guinea. The camera watches and assesses as the travellers meet the natives who live in the villages along the route. The two sides tell their own stories, revealing to the viewer the comparisons between them. Above all, “Cannibal Tours” affords us a glimpse of the real reasons why “civilised” people wish to encounter the “primitive”. Rated: PG

results.title: Cannibal crusade
results.brief_description: As seen on ATN 7 The World around us. A record of a month long expedition by Greg Grainger to Irian Jaya to observe the rituals and customs of two remote highland tribes in the Baliem Valley. Anthropologists believe that the Asmats of Senggo in the rainforests are the last surviving culture to occasionally practise cannibalism, head hunting and ritualised warfare. Shows aspects of the Dani way of life in Wamena.

results.title: Canoeing: The Basic Skills
results.creator_credit: Ed Brumby, C Bartlett, Vincent Drane and G Pedicini
results.brief_description: This program provides instructors and teachers with demonstration models, analyses of good technique and a summary of major coaching points for teaching basic flat water skills and white water manoeuvres to novice paddlers in Canadian c1 and c2 canoes. It includes points about equipment and safety, turning strokes, forward and reverse paddling, support strokes, ferry glides, breaks ins and outs and capsize drill.

results.title: Cane toads: an unnatural history. The Natural history of the chicken [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Mark Lewis, Tristram Miall, Mark Lewis Radio Pictures and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Cane toads: an unnatural history: “Bufo Marinus”, the cane toad, was introduced into Queensland in 1935 for a specific reason - to combat the grey-back beetle that was destroying the sugar cane crop. The mission failed: the beetle could fly and the cane toad couldn’t. Oblivious of its failure, the cane toad settled extremely well into its new surroundings and proceeded to breed so rapidly that it has now become a pest of plague proportions. This amusing documentary blends biological fact with human comment to show how the cane toads have become an accepted part of local culture and popular mythology. “The Natural history of the chicken”: Chickens are special creatures, not just something that are consumed by Americans to the tune of $40 billion per year in poultry products. This entertaining documentary spends time with people who are passionate about chickens. In Harpswell, Maine, a woman has 16 chickens, each with their own unique personality. There’s a recreation of a tense day in which chicken number 7 got lost out in the cold, froze, almost died, but was brought back to life by her owner. Time is also spent speaking to a farmer who raises chickens for consumption, the phenomenon of the rooster and the infamy of the “headless” chicken. Footage is also presented of battery hens and an egg hatchery, the scenes passed over without comment, just text on the screen, stark statistics quantifying the actions depicted. Dedicated to the renowned Italian Renaissance natural historian, Ulisse Aldrovandi.
results.title_for_label: Cane toads: an unnatural history. The Natural history of the chicken [DVD]

results.title: Cannonball
results.creator_credit: Gary Templeton, John Sturner, Firehouse Productions and Evergreen Films
results.brief_description: A delightful children’s story about Cannonball, a little stray dog who escapes from a pound and wanders into a circus. Here he is befriended by the clown who is in danger of losing his job unless he smartens up his act. Cannonball saves the day and acquires a role in the circus routine. Based on the book “Cannonball Simp”, written and illustrated by John Burningham. Minimal dialogue and features a cameo role by Joe Mantegna. Suitable for lower and middle primary levels.
